Redundancy-Related Bounds for Generalized Huffman Codes

Abstract

This paper presents new lower and upper bounds for the compression rate of binary prefix codes optimized over memoryless sources according to various nonlinear codeword length objectives. Like the most well-known redundancy bounds for minimum average redundancy coding â€” Huffman coding â€” these are in terms of a form of entropy and/or the probability of an input symbol, often the most probable one. The bounds here, some of which are tight, improve on known bounds of the form Lâˆˆ[H,H+1)ğ¿ğ»ğ»1L\in[H,H+1)italic_L âˆˆ [ italic_H , italic_H + 1 ), where Hğ»Hitalic_H is some form of entropy in bits (or, in the case of redundancy objectives,Â 00) and Lğ¿Litalic_L is the length objective, also in bits. The objectives explored here include exponential-average length, maximum pointwise redundancy, and exponential-average pointwise redundancy (also called dğ‘‘ditalic_dth exponential redundancy). The first of these relates to various problems involving queueing, uncertainty, and lossless communications; the second relates to problems involving Shannon coding and universal modeling. For these two objectives we also explore the related problem of the necessary and sufficient conditions for the shortest codeword of a code being a specific length.exponential redundancy). The first of these relates to various problems involving queueing, uncertainty, and lossless communications; the second relates to problems involving Shannon coding and universal modeling. For these two objectives we also explore the related problem of the necessary and sufficient conditions for the shortest codeword of a code being a specific length.

I Introduction

Since Shannon introduced information theory, we have had entropy bounds for the expected codeword length of optimal lossless fixed-to-variable-length binary codes. The lower bound is entropy, while the upper bound is one bit greater â€” corresponding to a maximum average redundancy of one bit for an optimal code â€” thus yielding unit-sized bounds. The upper bound follows from the suboptimal Shannon code, a code for which the codeword length of an input of probability pğ‘pitalic_p is âŒˆ-log2â¡pâŒ‰subscript2ğ‘\lceil-\log_{2}p\rceilâŒˆ - roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p âŒ‰[1].

Huffman found a method of producing an optimal code by building a tree in which the two nodes with lowest weight (probability) are merged to produce a node with their combined weight summed[2]. On the occasion of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Huffman algorithm, Gallager introduced bounds in terms of the most probable symbol which improved on the unit-sized redundancy bound[3]. Since then, improvements in both upper and lower bounds given this most probable symbol[4, 5, 6, 7, 8] have yielded bounds that are tight when this symbolâ€™s probability is at least 1/12711271/1271 / 127 (and close-to-tight when it has lower probability). Tight bounds also exist for upper and lower bounds given the less-specific information of an arbitrary symbolâ€™s probability[9, 10]. Such bounds are useful for quickly bounding the performance of an optimal code without running the algorithm that would produce the code. The bounds are for a fixed-sized input alphabet; asymptotic treatment of redundancy for block codes of growing size, based on binary memoryless sources, is given in [11].

Others have given consideration to objectives other than expected codeword length[12, Â§2.6]. Many of these nonlinear objectives, which have a variety of applications, also have unit-sized bounds but have heretofore lacked tighter closed-form bounds achieved using a symbol probability and, if necessary, some form of entropy. We address such problems here, finding upper and lower bounds for the optimal codes of given probability mass functions for nonlinear objectives. â€œOptimalâ€ in this paper refers to optimality over the objective in question, not necessarily over the linear objective of expectation.

A prefix code â€” also referred to as a comma-free code, a prefix-free code, or an instantaneous code â€” is a code for which no codeword begins with a sequence that also comprises the whole of a second codeword.

This problem is equivalent to finding a minimum-weight external path among all rooted binary trees, due to the fact that every prefix code can be represented as a binary tree. In this tree representation, each edge from a parent node to a child node is labeled 00 (left) or 1111 (right), with at most one of each type of edge per parent node. A leaf is a node without children; this corresponds to a codeword, and the codeword is determined by the path from the root to the leaf. Thus, for example, a leaf that is the right-edge (1111) child of a left-edge (00) child of a left-edge (00) child of the root will correspond to codewordÂ 001001001001. Leaf depth (distance from the root) is thus codeword length. If we represent external path weight as âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’³wâ¢(i)â¢lisubscriptğ‘–ğ’³ğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}w(i)l_{i}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_i ) italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the weights are the probabilities (i.e., wâ¢(i)=piğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–w(i)=p_{i}italic_w ( italic_i ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and, in fact, we refer to the problem inputs as {wâ¢(i)}ğ‘¤ğ‘–\{w(i)\}{ italic_w ( italic_i ) } for certain generalizations in which their sum, âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’³wâ¢(i)subscriptğ‘–ğ’³ğ‘¤ğ‘–\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}w(i)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_i ), need not beÂ 1111.

Because Huffmanâ€™s algorithm[2] finds codes minimizing average redundancy (1), the minimum-average redundancy problem itself is often referred to as the â€œHuffman problem,â€ even though the problem did not originate with Huffman himself. Huffmanâ€™s algorithm is a greedy algorithm built on the observation that the two least likely items will have the same length and can thus be considered siblings in the coding tree. A reduction is thus made in which the two items of weights wâ¢(i)ğ‘¤ğ‘–w(i)italic_w ( italic_i ) and wâ¢(j)ğ‘¤ğ‘—w(j)italic_w ( italic_j ) are considered as one with combined weight wâ¢(i)+wâ¢(j)ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¤ğ‘—w(i)+w(j)italic_w ( italic_i ) + italic_w ( italic_j ). The codeword of the combined item determines all but the last bit of each of the items combined, which are differentiated by this last bit. This reduction continues until there is one item left, and, assigning this item the null string, a code is defined for all input items. In the corresponding optimal code tree, the iğ‘–iitalic_ith leaf corresponds to the codeword of the iğ‘–iitalic_ith input item, and thus has weight wâ¢(i)ğ‘¤ğ‘–w(i)italic_w ( italic_i ), whereas the weight of parent nodes are determined by the combined weight of the corresponding merged item.

All of the nonlinear objectives we consider have been shown to be solved by generalized versions of the Huffman algorithm[14, 15, 16, 17, 18]. These generalizations change the combining rule; instead of replacing items iğ‘–iitalic_i and jğ‘—jitalic_j with an item of weight wâ¢(i)+wâ¢(j)ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¤ğ‘—w(i)+w(j)italic_w ( italic_i ) + italic_w ( italic_j ), the generalized algorithm replaces them with an item of weight fâ¢(wâ¢(i),wâ¢(j))ğ‘“ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘¤ğ‘—f(w(i),w(j))italic_f ( italic_w ( italic_i ) , italic_w ( italic_j ) ) for some functionÂ fğ‘“fitalic_f. The weight of a combined item (a node) therefore need not be equal to the sum of the probabilities of the items merged to create it (the sum of the leaves of the corresponding subtree). Thus the sum of weights in a reduced problem need not beÂ 1111, unlike in the original Huffman algorithm. In particular, the weight of the root, wrootsubscriptğ‘¤rootw_{\mathop{\rm root}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, need not beÂ 1111. However, we continue to assume that the sum of inputs to the coding problems will beÂ 1111 (with the exception of reductions among problems).

The next section introduces the objectives of interest, along with their motivations and our main contributions. These contributions, indicated by ( â˜ ), are bounds on performance of optimal codes according to their optimizing objectives, as well as related properties. We defer the formal presentation of these contributions, along with proofs, until later sections, where they are presented as theorems and corollaries, along with the remarks immediately following them and associated figures. II Objectives, Motivations, and Main Results

An extension of Shannon coding introduced by Blumer and McEliece[21, p.Â 1244] to upper-bound the problem considered in SectionÂ II-C was later rediscovered and efficiently implemented by Drmota and Szpankowski as a solution to this maximum pointwise redundancy problem. Applications in prior literature

The solution of this worst-case pointwise redundancy problem is relevant to optimizing maximal (worst-case) minimax redundancy, a universal modeling problem (as in [23, p.Â 176]) for which the set ğ’«ğ’«{\mathcal{P}}caligraphic_P of possible probability distributions results in a normalized â€œmaximum likelihood distribution.â€[20] More recently Gawrychowski and Gagie proposed a second worst-case redundancy problem which also finds its solution in minimizing maximum pointwise redundancy[24]. For this problem, normalization is not relevant and one allows any probability distribution that is consistent with an empirical distribution based on sampling.

Prior and current results

The first proposed algorithm for the maximum pointwise redundancy problem is a codeword-wise improvement on the Shannon code in the sense that each codeword is the same length as or one bit shorter than the corresponding codeword in the Shannon code. This method is called â€œgeneralized Shannon coding.â€ (With proper tie-breaking techniques, the Huffman-like solution guarantees that each codeword, in turn, is no longer than the generalized Shannon codeword. As both methods guarantee optimality, this makes no difference in the maximum pointwise redundancy.) Notice a property true of Shannon codes â€” generalized or not â€” but not minimum average redundancy (Huffman) codes: Because any given codeword has a length lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT not exceeding âŒˆ-lgâ¡piâŒ‰lgsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–\lceil-\lg p_{i}\rceilâŒˆ - roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŒ‰, this length is within one bit of the associated input symbolâ€™s self-information, -lgâ¡pilgsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–-\lg p_{i}- roman_lg italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This results in bounds of Ropt*â¢(ğ’‘)âˆˆ[0,1)superscriptsubscriptğ‘…optğ’‘01R_{\mathop{\rm opt}}^{*}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})\in[0,1)italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_opt end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ), which are improved upon in SectionÂ III. The bound can also be considered a degenerative case from a result of Shtarkov [23, p.Â 176], that for which the probabilities are fully known.

Applications (a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1)

We add an additional observation on a modified version of this problem: Suppose there are a sequence of windows of opportunities rather than only one. The probability that a window stays open long enough to send a message of length lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is alisuperscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–a^{l_{i}}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since each additional bit has independent probability ağ‘aitalic_a of getting through. Thus, given lisubscriptğ‘™ğ‘–l_{i}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the expected number of windows needed to send a message â€” assuming it is necessary to resend communication for each window â€” is the multiplicative inverse of this. Overall expectation is therefore

Although such a resending of communications is usually not needed for a constant message, this problem is a notable dual to the first problem. In this dual problem, we seek to minimize the expectation of a growing exponential of lengths rather than maximize the expectation of a decaying exponential.

Originally, the a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1 variation of (6) was used in Humbletâ€™s dissertation[30] for a queueing application originally proposed by Jelinek[31] and expounded upon in [21]. This problem is one in which overflow probability should be minimized, where the source produces symbols randomly and the codewords are temporarily stored in a finite buffer. In this problem, there exists an a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1 such that optimizing Laâ¢(ğ’‘,ğ’)subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ’‘ğ’L_{a}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$l$}})italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p , bold_italic_l ) optimizes this problem; the correct ağ‘aitalic_a is found through iteration. The Huffman-like coding method was simultaneously published in [14, 15, 28]; in the last of these, Humblet noted that the Huffman combining method (7) finds the optimal code with aâˆˆ(0,1)ğ‘01a\in(0,1)italic_a âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) as well.

More recently, the a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1 variation was shown to have a third application[32]. In this problem, the true probability of the source is not known; it is only known that the relative entropy between the true probability and ğ’‘ğ’‘pbold_italic_p is within some known bound. As in Humbletâ€™s queueing problem, there is an a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1, found via iteration, such that optimizing Laâ¢(ğ’‘,ğ’)subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ’‘ğ’L_{a}({\mbox{\boldmath$p$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$l$}})italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_p , bold_italic_l ) solves the problem.

Prior and current results

Note that aâ†’1â†’ğ‘1a\rightarrow 1italic_a â†’ 1 corresponds to the usual linear expectation objective. Problems for ağ‘aitalic_a near 1111 are of special interest, since aâ†“1â†“ğ‘1a\downarrow 1italic_a â†“ 1 corresponds to the minimum-variance solution if the problem has multiple solutions â€” as noted in [15], among others â€” while aâ†‘1â†‘ğ‘1a\uparrow 1italic_a â†‘ 1 corresponds to the maximum-variance solution.

Most of the aforementioned improved bounds are based on a given highest symbol probability,Â p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We thus give this case special attention and also discuss the related property of the length of the most likely codeword in these coding problems. The bounds in this paper are the first of their kind for nontraditional Huffman codes, bounds which are, for Lasubscriptğ¿ğ‘L_{a}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, functions of both entropy and p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as in the traditional case. However, they are not the first improved bounds for such codes. More sophisticated bounds on the optimal solution for the exponential-average objective are given in [21] for a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1; these appear as solutions to related problems rather than in closed form, however, and these problems require no less time or space to solve than the original problem. They are mainly useful for analysis. Bounds given elsewhere for a closely related objective having a one-to-one correspondence with (6) are demonstrated under the assumption that p1â‰¥0.4subscriptğ‘10.4p_{1}\geq 0.4italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.4 always implies l1subscriptğ‘™1l_{1}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be 1111 for the optimal code[33]. We show that this is not necessarily the case due to the difference between the exponential-average objective and the usual objective of an arithmetic average.

Specifically, TheoremÂ 3 states that, for aâˆˆ(0.5,1]ğ‘0.51a\in(0.5,1]italic_a âˆˆ ( 0.5 , 1 ], a code with shortest codeword of length 1111 is optimal if p1â‰¥2â¢a/(2â¢a+3)subscriptğ‘12ğ‘2ğ‘3p_{1}\geq 2a/(2a+3)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 2 italic_a / ( 2 italic_a + 3 ). A few observations can be used to find a series of improved lower and upper bounds on optimum maximum pointwise redundancy based on (9):

Properties, Maximum Pointwise Redundancy

Lemma 1

Suppose we apply (3) to find a Huffman-like code tree in order to minimize maximum pointwise redundancy (RÂ¯â¢(ğ¥,ğ©)normal-Â¯ğ‘…ğ¥ğ©\bar{R}({\mbox{\boldmath$l$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})Â¯ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ( bold_italic_l , bold_italic_p ) given ğ©ğ©pbold_italic_p). Then the following holds:

  1. 1.

    Items are always merged by nondecreasing weight.

  2. 2.

    The weight of the root wrootsubscriptğ‘¤rootw_{\mathop{\rm root}}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the coding tree determines the maximum pointwise redundancy, R*â¢(ğ’,ğ’‘)=lgâ¡wrootsuperscriptğ‘…ğ’ğ’‘lgsubscriptğ‘¤rootR^{*}({\mbox{\boldmath$l$}},{\mbox{\boldmath$p$}})=\lg w_{\mathop{\rm root}}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_l , bold_italic_p ) = roman_lg italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_root end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  3. 3.

    The total probability of any subtree is no greater than the total weight of the subtree.

  4. 4.

    If p1â‰¤2â¢pn-1subscriptğ‘12subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1p_{1}\leq 2p_{n-1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 2 italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then a minimum maximum pointwise redundancy code can be represented by a complete tree, that is, a tree with leaves at depth âŒŠlgâ¡nâŒ‹lgğ‘›\lfloor\lg n\rfloorâŒŠ roman_lg italic_n âŒ‹ and âŒˆlgâ¡nâŒ‰lgğ‘›\lceil\lg n\rceilâŒˆ roman_lg italic_n âŒ‰ only (with âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’³2-li=1subscriptğ‘–ğ’³superscript2subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–1\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}2^{-l_{i}}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1). (This property is similar to the property noted in [34] for optimal-expected-length codes of sources termed quasi-uniform in [35].)

Proof:

We use an inductive proof in which base cases of sizes 1111 and 2222 are trivial, and we use weight function wğ‘¤witalic_w instead of probability mass functionÂ ğ’‘ğ’‘pbold_italic_p to emphasize that the sums of weights need not necessarily add up toÂ 1111. Assume first that all properties here are true for trees of size n-1ğ‘›1n-1italic_n - 1 and smaller. We wish to show that they are true for trees of sizeÂ nğ‘›nitalic_n.

For the third property, the first combined pair yields a weight that is no less than the combined probabilities. Thus, via induction, the total probability of any (sub)tree is no greater than the weight of the (sub)tree.

In order to show the final property, first note that âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’³2-li=1subscriptğ‘–ğ’³superscript2subscriptğ‘™ğ‘–1\sum_{i\in{\mathcal{X}}}2^{-l_{i}}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ caligraphic_X end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 for any tree created using the Huffman-like procedure, since all internal nodes have two children. Now think of the procedure as starting with a (priority) queue of input items, ordered by nondecreasing weight from head to tail. After merging two items, obtained from the head of the queue, into one compound item, that item is placed back into the queue as one item, but not necessarily at the tail; an item is placed such that its weight is no smaller than any item ahead of it and is smaller than any item behind it. In keeping items ordered, this results in an optimal coding tree. A variant of this method can be used for linear-time coding[18].

In this case, we show not only that an optimal complete tree exists, but that, given an nğ‘›nitalic_n-item tree, all items that finish at level âŒˆlgâ¡nâŒ‰lgğ‘›\lceil\lg n\rceilâŒˆ roman_lg italic_n âŒ‰ appear closer to the head of the queue than any item at level âŒˆlgâ¡nâŒ‰-1lgğ‘›1\lceil\lg n\rceil-1âŒˆ roman_lg italic_n âŒ‰ - 1 (if any), using a similar approach to the proof of LemmaÂ 2 in [29]. V-C2 a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1

Given a>1ğ‘1a>1italic_a > 1 and p1<1subscriptğ‘11p_{1}<1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, we wish to show that a probability distribution always exists such that there is no optimal code with l1=1subscriptğ‘™11l_{1}=1italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. We first show that, for the exponential penalties as for the traditional Huffman penalty, every optimal ğ’ğ’lbold_italic_l can be obtained via the (modified) Huffman procedure. That is, if multiple length vectors are optimal, each optimal length vector can be obtained by the Huffman procedure as long as ties are broken in a certain manner.

Clearly the optimal code is obtained for n=2ğ‘›2n=2italic_n = 2. Let nâ€²superscriptğ‘›â€²n^{\prime}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the smallest nğ‘›nitalic_n for which there is an ğ’ğ’lbold_italic_l that is optimal but cannot be obtained via the algorithm. Since ğ’ğ’lbold_italic_l is optimal, consider the two smallest probabilities, pnâ€²subscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘›â€²p_{n^{\prime}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pnâ€²-1subscriptğ‘superscriptğ‘›â€²1p_{n^{\prime}-1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this optimal code, two items having these probabilities (although not necessarily items nâ€²-1superscriptğ‘›â€²1n^{\prime}-1italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 and nâ€²superscriptğ‘›â€²n^{\prime}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) must have the longest codewords and must have the same codeword lengths. Were the latter not the case, the codeword of the more probable item could be exchanged with one of a less probable item, resulting in a better code. Were the former not the case, the longest codeword length could be decreased by one without violating the Kraft inequality, resulting in a better code. Either way, the code would no longer be optimal. Thus we can find two such smallest items with largest codewords (by breaking any ties properly), which, without loss of generality, can be considered siblings. Therefore the problem can be reduced to one of size nâ€²-1superscriptğ‘›â€²1n^{\prime}-1italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 via the exponential Huffman algorithm. But since all problems of size nâ€²-1superscriptğ‘›â€²1n^{\prime}-1italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 can be solved via the algorithm, this is a contradiction, and the Huffman algorithm can thus find any optimal code.

Note that this is not true for minimizing maximum pointwise redundancy, as the exchange argument no longer holds. This is why the sufficient condition of SectionÂ III was not verified using Huffman-like methods.
